Blog.post: I was at the zoo this weekend to do my normal exhibit interpreting (talking to bratty kids about how cheetahs have spots, etc.) and some really cool stuff happened, namely that we bred two young cats together and may have cubs in November. There was a lot of activity all day with Amadi (the male cat) stuttering and yelping all afternoon, which is basically him saying "I'd like to get laid again, get over here you bitch!" For those of you who don't know, cheetahs are the only large cat that does not roar, but they have a whole slew of other cool noises. I also got to see Jomu, one of our older females, charge around the yard growling while the keepers tried to get her to go inside. Needless to say, Jomu won and got to stay in her yard. Since I am a moron, as previously stated, who also can't put up links to photos, I made a little album on Shutterfly so you can see some pics I took of our cats and our Grevy's zebras (which are a HIGHLY endangered species, btw - only about 3000 left in the wild). You can see them by clicking on the link below. There are also pics of some of our other animals, including a few I took of the pandas. now there's this: ...Before attending a rally to hear Vice President Dick Cheney, citizens in New Mexico were required to sign a political loyalty oath approved by the Republican National Committee. "I, (full name) ... do herby (sic) endorse George W. Bush for reelection of the United States." The form noted: "In signing the above endorsement you are consenting to use and release of your name by Bush-Cheney as an endorser of President Bush." Around the country, Bush is campaigning at events billed as "Ask President Bush." Only supporters are allowed entrance. Talking points are distributed to questioners... -from salon.com's Sidney Blumenthal in his column "Isn't this a Democracy?" ( urlLink http://www.salon.com/opinion/blumenthal /2004/08/19/ask_bush/index.html ) Why aren't more people, even Bush supporters, more alarmed by things like this? Since when did it become acceptable to keep the president from hearing ANY disagreement with his policies from the citizens he's supposed to serve?
